item.title: By: Janice Lee
item.dc:creator: Janice Lee
item.content:encoded:
Hi on-p-n-t,

Good article. Really! Thanks. Follow-up question üôÇ

Suppose I’m using log shipping and because of changes in data latency requirement, I’m forced to perform more frequent restores and users are of course getting kicked out while the restores are ongoing. Suppose replication isn’t a viable replacement (let’s say I have valid reasons that I refuse to enumerate :P). Suppose I approach as you discussed on this post, I’d have to

1) drop the snapshot and recreate it every X hours. During this time, the snapshot wouldn’t be accessible, right? This would probably be equivalent to the users getting kicked out which I want to avoid. üôÅ Or I can…
2) create a new snapshot every time and let my reporting app switch to the new snapshot once it’s created. Or i can…
3) just keep my current log shipping setup, add a second destination…then somehow let my reporting app connect to this 2nd destination when restore is ongoing in the first one. Then switch again when done. Makes sense?

Oy! Replication’s starting to look “prettier and prettier”.

item.title: By: Jorge Segarra
item.dc:creator: Jorge Segarra
item.description: Good article but one thing to mention. When you're in a mirroring setup you don't have to purchase a new license for the mirrored instance so long as its non-active (read also: not using it for reporting purposes). Once you create snapshots on the mirror then you need to license that second instance.
item.content:encoded: Good article but one thing to mention. When you’re in a mirroring setup you don’t have to purchase a new license for the mirrored instance so long as its non-active (read also: not using it for reporting purposes). Once you create snapshots on the mirror then you need to license that second instance.
